    What is the future of privacy?
    Rod Graham, Awkward offline, Awkwa...     — I am a bit worried about what the future holds.  There are too many entities out there that can profit by knowing who does what on the Internet.   … 
    1. First and foremost, gove...
     
    (more)Loading...
    5
     
    Rod Graham, Awkward offline, Awkward online...Awkward offline, Awkward online...
    Votes by
    Alison Stone,
    Marc Bodnick,
    Vikas Sharma, and
    Chris Watson.
    I am a bit worried about what the future holds.  There are too many entities out there that can profit by knowing who does what on the Internet. 

    1. First and foremost, governments simply do not like the Internet the way it is now where people cannot be tracked (and this goes not just for more centralized governments like China, but also for western democratic governments as well).  I worry that they may find ways to force code to be written that tracks all online.  Or, create a law that indirectly tracks someone...like an Internet ID that everyone must use to go on select sites.   I worry that someone is going to write some very malicious code that disables the network, and scares people so much that they are willing to vote for some version type of cyberpatriot act.
    2. Marketers want to know who clicks what.  That way they can better fine tune their sales pitches.  For example, Google is benign enough...but even they would prefer it if you use location search, and most people don't think about the cookies that accumulate on their computers.  Companies will become more sophisticated in tracking people simply because it is in their best interest to do so.

    I think the future of privacy hinges on the digital literacy of the population.  If people are aware of what is at stake, they will be less likely to vote for some form of patriot act and they can avoid the maneuverings of marketers.
    19 Dec, 2011

    4th Amendment
    "The right of the people to be secure in their persons, houses, papers, and effects, against unreasonable searches and seizures, shall not be violated, and no warrants shall issue, but upon probable cause, supported by oath or affirmation, and particularly describing the place to be searched, and the persons or things to be seized."

    This is significant. It is not partially important, it is not antiquated. It is either part of our U.S. Constitution or it is not. If it is antiquated, it should be debated and modified by the Legislature. Privacy includes "effects". The reason for this amendment is to protect the citizenry from being snooped on without a search warrant. This has changed under recent laws and terrorist activities, but does not give the government free rein. We have seen what can happen lately vis á vis the NSA and AP and IRS snooping adventures.
    Via
    David McKerracher.

    What are the best privacy practices for startups?
    Stephen Grody     — Your lawyer will give you the must-haves.  But, here's a management policy most leaders forget:  After defining your back-office, you might run a "murder board" review.  Th... 
    (more)Loading...
    4
     
    Stephen Grody
    Votes by
    Georges Duplessy,
    Jen Harvey, and
    Jon Pincus.
    Your lawyer will give you the must-haves.  But, here's a management policy most leaders forget:  After defining your back-office, you might run a "murder board" review.  The idea is to assemble a small group of astute aggressors, charge them with hostile intent toward your company, then disclose the entire design.  Your company's role is essentially "custodian of customer information".  The questions to the board are:
     1. How would you break into our systems from the outside?
     2. How would you break into our systems from the inside (e.g., as employee)
     3. Once "in", what information would you take?
     4. Once taken, what could be done with the information copied?
     5. What would happen if all information copied were posted in on the net
         in the clear? 
    The exercise will sharpen your thinking.  Run the drill more than once in the life of your company.  The objective isn't to protect yourself from being sued by an unhappy (class of) customer(s) ... the objective is to protect your brand from an unrecoverable event. 

    Make sure your employees know they need to check with management before extracting and sharing copies of any the back-office data with anyone ... even if only test data for developers.

    How does Facebook Places check-in privacy work?

    Ben Gertzfield, Coder on Facebook PlacesCoder on Facebook Places
    Votes by
    Keith Adams, Engineer at Facebook    ,
    Justin Mitchell, Former Facebook Engineering Manager for Photos ...    ,
    Aaron Chiu, Software Engineer at Facebook    ,
    Russell Stadler, and 16 moreLoading....
    Similar to Facebook Photos, the rules for who can see your Places check-ins are pretty complicated. Unlike Photos, Places check-ins have special rules for minors.  In addition, you only see check-ins from your friends on Place Pages (for example, http://facebook.com/facebookhq?s...), so further visibility rules apply.

    These rules apply in order. These are current as of January, 2011.

    1. Are you viewing a check-in on a Place Page? We only show check-ins from you and your friends, or in which you or your friends have been tagged.
    2. Are you viewing a check-in on a Place Page in which a friend was tagged? We'll only show that friend after they've opted in to using Facebook Places.
    3. Are you viewing a check-in on a friend's profile in which they were tagged? We'll only show that check-in after your friend has opted in to using Facebook Places.
    4. Did you author the check-in, or were you tagged in it? You can always see a check-in you authored or were tagged in.
    5. Is the author of the check-in a minor? We'll only show it to the author's friends, even if the minor widens their privacy setting and/or tags your friends in the check-in.
    6. Are any of the tagged users minors? We'll only show them to their friends, even if the author has a wider privacy setting.
    7. Have any of the tagged users opted out of using Facebook Places after they were tagged? If so, we won't show them in the check-in.
    8. Were you blocked by the author of the check-in, or have you blocked the author of the check-in? If so, you can never see the check-in.
    9. Were you blocked by a tagged user, or have you blocked a tagged user? You won't see those users.
    10. If you're not friends with the author but you are friends with at least one visible tagged user, and the author's overall privacy is set to "Recommended", "Friends Only", or "Friends of Friends", does the author have the privacy setting "Share a tagged post with friends of the friend I tag" enabled? If so, you can see the check-in.
    11. Are you included in the author's "Places I check in to" privacy setting? If so, you can see the check-in.
    12. Otherwise, you can't see the check-in.

    The separate "Here Now" feature on Place Pages shows your friends who are currently checked in to that Place (modulo the rules above).

    If you check in to the Place yourself, you can additionally see friends and non-friends who are currently checked in, if they have the "Include me in "People Here Now" after I check in" setting enabled (excluding minors and users who have blocked you).

    It means to surround oneself with so many false trails, so much information that is not pertinent to oneself, that the self cannot be discovered.

    If, for example, I have one, important five-letter word and hide it among 2,000 other five-letter words, it is not a trivial exercise for you to discover my word.

    1
     
    David Brin, My book The Transparent Society: Will Technology force us to choose between Privacy and Freedom a... (more) My book The Transparent Society: Will Technology force us to choose between Privacy and Freedom addressed issues of secrecy, privacy, secrecy and transparency.
    This question buys into the notion of a Zero Sum Game ZSG which means we must trade one good thing for another... security for freedom... accountability for privacy.  It is simply not true.  Positive Sum Games are what our civilization has been about for 200 years.  We have more security, freedom, accountability and privacy than all other generations combined, yet people buy into ZSG.

    Read Robert Wright's NONZERO. Steven Pinker's THE BETTER ANGELS. And of course my own The Transparent Society: Will Technology Make Us Choose Between Privacy and Freedom?   There in chapter 4 I discuss the importance of privacy and how the ONLY way we will have any, in the future, is in a mostly open world where we can catch those who stare at us...

    ...exactly as we can in a restaurant.

    Francesco Bovoli, VP, Programme Management & Infrastructure - WorkshareVP, Programme Management & Infrastructure - Workshare
    Vote by
    Antonio Messina.
    I am confused whether you are asking:

    1. Should governments implement part of their information systems on public cloud Infrastructure-as-a-Service providers, such as Amazon or RackSpace
    2. Should governments IT agencies build their own private G-Cloud, becoming internal providers of IaaS services to other parts of the government

    Since you are asking in terms of data privacy and security, I would say that (1) is probably not a good idea, (2) is.

    (more)Loading...
    1
     
    Jon Mixon, I run a businessI run a business
    Advertising as proven itself to more a symbiote than a parasite to business. Business has a finite number of customers it can attract by simply hanging out a "shingle" (or a web page) or by word of mouth and beyond that point, advertisers and advertising are required.

    Advertiser do generate "value" on their own by employing printing companies, photographers, web site designers and many ancillary businesses to create their advertising campaigns. They also allow obscure business and brands to reach wider audiences creating additional value for the marketplace as well keeping established businesses "top of mind".

    While, like any business, some advertisers have abused their positions and have exploited the public,the fact that is this known states that there are efficient controls in place to protect the market.

    How, if at all, will cargo airlines become pilotless?
    Answer Wiki — The initial interest would be for small and dangerous cargo loads, where urgency and privacy is paramount (due to nature of cargo or the origin/destination).… 
    (more)Loading...
    Most agree that the broad technology for this is available, and scaling up from the current UAVs won't be too difficult. Also, most agree that it makes excellent sense for unmanned drones (unmanned only because the pilot is not in the cockpit but in front of a computer in a room) in warfare (overt and covert) and could also be useful for specific tasks (corporate espionage, small package delivery)
    But the incremental utility which a pilot-less cargo jet will bring to a logistics business is doubtful, at least for now. There is already minimal harm to human life, plus the weight and volume reduction in a cargo plane due to missing pilots will be nominal.
    The initial interest would be for small and dangerous cargo loads, where urgency and privacy is paramount (due to nature of cargo or the origin/destination).
    ★
    How do you subscribe or unsubscribe to the Quora Weekly Digest?
    Answer Wiki — If you are sure the digest isn't being sent (ie: it is enabled in your settings, and you've tried changing your login email to avoid filters), email privacy@quora.com… 
    (more)Loading...
    1. Go to your Settings page.
    2. Click on Email Preferences --> Activity on Content You Follow
    3. Toggle the setting "Send me a weekly digest of top content on Quora"
    4. If you are not receiving the digest, the digest is possibly being filtered as spam (Hotmail does this) -- try changing your Quora primary login email to an ISP-provided address, or add Quora.com to a whitelist.
    5. If you are sure the digest isn't being sent (ie: it is enabled in your settings, and you've tried changing your login email to avoid filters), email privacy@quora.com

    What's the minimum age requirement for registering on Quora?
    Answer Wiki — A user must be 13+ years old to sign up for Quora.  From quora.com... :   > Children's Privacy  Protecting the privacy of young children is especially important. Quora does not knowingly collect or solicit personal information from anyone under the age of 13 or knowingly allow such persons to register with the Service… 
    (more)Loading...
    A user must be 13+ years old to sign up for Quora.

    From http://www.quora.com/about/privacy :

    Children's Privacy

    Protecting the privacy of young children is especially important. Quora does not knowingly collect or solicit personal information from anyone under the age of 13 or knowingly allow such persons to register with the Service. If we become aware that we have collected personal information from a child under age 13, we take steps to remove that information.
